body:
Hi James , 
Is any Update for this issue ?

issue.title: [2.2.x] Error "*/*:playRunHooks is undefined" on running as web/run

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Previously reported as:
- [How to create a Play 2.2 Scala application as an SBT sub-project](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18968952)
- [Debugging Play 2.2 subproject?](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23642691/) on Stackoverflow
- [Running a Play subproject from sbt](https://groups.google.com/d/msg/play-framework/AYgKC02RU1E/mrI6eR54PF0J) on mailing list
- etc
## steps

Make multi-project structure that uses Play 2.2:

```
hello/
  +- common/
  |    + ...
  +- core/
  |    + ...
  +- web/
  |    +- app/
  |    +- conf/
  |    + ...
  +- project
  +- build.sbt
```

Try running it from the root directory `hello` as:

```
$ sbt web/run
```
## problem

Apparently this results to 

```
java.lang.RuntimeException: */*:playRunHooks is undefined.
        at scala.sys.package$.error(package.scala:27)
[trace] Stack trace suppressed: run last web/compile:run for the full output.
[error] (web/compile:run) */*:playRunHooks is undefined.
```
## notes

I think this was enbugged in #1456 [f71f84](https://github.com/playframework/playframework/commit/f71f845ffc9c104ee56de9016d099aff85d8427e#diff-54bc87264db9f4a61f09995511c80f56R85):

``` scala
        val (_, hooks) = extracted.runTask(playRunHooks, state)
```

but it seems to gotten fixed by chance in later commits and maybe #3108. As it was backported to 2.3.x (?), the problem no longer exists on 2.3.7. I reported this for documentation purpose. Feel free to close this.
## workaround for 2.2 users

``` scala
$ sbt "project web" run
```

or 

``` scala
lazy val root = (project in file(".")).
  settings(
    playRunHooks := Nil,
    playInteractionMode := play.PlayConsoleInteractionMode,
    playDefaultPort := 9000,
    playMonitoredFiles := (Def.taskDyn {
      val s = state.value
      s.history.current.split("/").headOption match {
        case Some(ref) =>
          Def.task {
            (playMonitoredFiles in LocalProject(ref)).value
          }
        case _ =>
          Def.task {
            playMonitoredFiles.value
          }
      } 
    }).value
  )
```

body:
I have the same issue. - 

> [warn] play - No application found at invoker init
> [error] application -
> ! Internal server error, for (GET) [/] ->

when I switch to subproject, effect is different - classloader can't see classes from dependend modules.
I have Build.scala with following structure

```
lazy val prCommon = Project(id="pr-common", base = file("pr-common"))
lazy val prPlay = Project(id="pr-play", base = file("pr-play"), settings = buildSettings ++ PlayScala.projectSettings)
    .enablePlugins(PlayScala).dependsOn(prCommon).aggregate(prCommon)
```

If I run `pr-play/run` from sbt - I get [warn] play - No application found at invoker init
if I switch to `project pr-play` and then issue `run` I get 

> Caused by: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: [class from prCommon module]
> at play.api.GlobalSettings$class.onError(GlobalSettings.scala:148) ~[play_2.10-2.3.6.jar:2.3.6]

so I can't make play2 project a module in larger sbt build. play 2.3.6, sbt 0.13.5

I traced this problem down to following files:

```
./src/play/src/main/scala/play/core/server/NettyServer.scala:        val appProvider = new ReloadableApplication(buildLink, buildDocHandler)

./src/play/src/main/scala/play/core/system/ApplicationProvider.scala:class ReloadableApplication(buildLink: BuildLink, buildDocHandler: BuildDocHandler) extends ApplicationProvider

./src/play/src/main/scala/play/core/server/NettyServer.scala:  def mainDevHttpMode(buildLink: BuildLink, buildDocHandler: BuildDocHandler, httpPort: Int): NettyServer = {

./src/sbt-plugin/src/main/scala/PlayRun.scala:          val mainDev = mainClass.getMethod("mainDevHttpMode", classOf[BuildLink], classOf[BuildDocHandler], classOf[Int])

./src/sbt-plugin/src/main/scala/PlayReloader.scala:  def newReloader(state: State,

./src/sbt-plugin/src/main/scala/PlayRun.scala:    lazy val reloader = newReloader(state, playReload, reloaderClassLoader, reloaderClasspathTask, assetsLoader,
```

I don't know that code, but I suspect that either Build link is not constructed properly, or PlayRun does not pass proper BuildLink parameter to NettyServer

issue.title: Play project doesn't work if it is not the root

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
**project/build.properties**

```
sbt.version=0.13.7
```

**project/plugins.sbt**

``` scala
addSbtPlugin("com.typesafe.play" % "sbt-plugin" % "2.3.7")
```

**build.sbt**

``` scala
lazy val foo = (project in file("foo")).enablePlugins(PlayScala)
```

After `sbt foo/run` and `curl http://localhost:9000/`, there is the exception

```
! Internal server error, for (GET) [/] ->

java.util.NoSuchElementException: None.get
    at scala.None$.get(Option.scala:313) ~[scala-library.jar:na]
    at scala.None$.get(Option.scala:311) ~[scala-library.jar:na]
    at play.PlayReloader$$anon$1.reload(PlayReloader.scala:89) ~[na:na]
    at play.core.ReloadableApplication$$anonfun$get$1.apply(ApplicationProvider.scala:122) ~[play_2.10-2.3.7.jar:2.3.7]
    at play.core.ReloadableApplication$$anonfun$get$1.apply(ApplicationProvider.scala:120) ~[play_2.10-2.3.7.jar:2.3.7]
```

If I change `file("foo")` to `file(".")`, it works.

But this significantly limits what I can do. E.g. I want to have SBT project with a couple dozen projects that share code, including a few Play projects.

body:
Are these the same problem (`mysubproject/run` or `use mysubproject; run`) or different ones?

I'd love to see this fixed.

I'm trying to figure out `playReload` and scopes, etc., but I'm new to SBT. If someone knows anything that could help, let me know.

``` scala
lazy val commonProject =  Project(id="commonProject", base = file("common-project"))

lazy val playProject = Project(id="playProject", base=file("play-base"), settings = PlayScala.projectSettings).enablePlugins(PlayScala).dependsOn(commonProject).aggregate(commonProject)

lazy val mainProject =  Project("Main", file(".")).dependsOn(commonProject)

lazy val root = project.aggregate(mainProject, playProject)
```

then:

case A - running from sbt root context

when I go to sbt, and run
`playProject/run`
Then I try to reach a page that should be served, I get:

`--- (Running the application, auto-reloading is enabled) ---
[info] play - Listening for HTTP on /0:0:0:0:0:0:0:0:9000
(Server started, use Ctrl+D to stop and go back to the console...)
[error] application -
! Internal server error, for (GET) [/] ->
java.util.NoSuchElementException: None.get
    at scala.None$.get(Option.scala:313) ~[scala-library.jar:na]
    at scala.None$.get(Option.scala:311) ~[scala-library.jar:na]
    at play.PlayReloader$$anon$1.reload(PlayReloader.scala:89) ~[na:na]
    at play.core.ReloadableApplication$$anonfun$get$1.apply(ApplicationProvider.scala:122) ~[play_2.10-2.3.7.jar:2.3.7]
    at play.core.ReloadableApplication$$anonfun$get$1.apply(ApplicationProvider.scala:120) ~[play_2.10-2.3.7.jar:2.3.7]
`

case B - running from playProject context

`project playProject`
`run`

In that case I got

`Caused by: java.lang.ClassNotFoundException: [class from commonProject module]`

@marekzebrowski, I too had this problem with the `project mysubproject` approach.

I was working on combining separate SBT projects into one project with subprojects.

Then I realized that in my mess of .scala and .sbt files, I was actually downloading old artifacts for the projects. I removed the old .sbt files (I had one in each project), and it worked. At least, I think that's what happened.

---

**tl;dr**

Using `project mysubproject` and `run`, rather than `mysubproject/run`, works (at least for me).
the workaround works for me as well. thanks.

issue.title: Fix #3484: mysubproject/run doesn't work

repository.name: playframework
repository.description: The Community Maintained High Velocity Web Framework For Java and Scala.

issue.body:
Fix #3484 by using `resolvedScope` when calling `Project#runTask`.

This can be trivially backported to 2.3.x.

---

There are other places where it seems there may be similar errors, but I am not well acquainted with them.

I was a little surprised at how frequently `Project#runTask` is used.

body:
@ms-tg Is it sufficient to pass multiple sbt commands via the command line?  For example:

```
sbt ';project mysubproject ; run'
```
See above for fix, are you on 2.3.x?  We should have a 2.3.x release with this fixed soon.

Ah excellent @jroper thank you. We are indeed on 2.3.x for the affected projects, so thank you, we will look for the release with the fix.

Separately, just within TIM Group, @jaramir can get back to @flicken on wither the "quotes and semicolon" workaround is sufficient for our uses?
